title: Lord Heseltine vows to join Brexit rebellion against Theresa May in Lords over Article 50
text:
Lord Heseltine vows to join Brexit rebellion against Theresa May in Lords over Article 50 Lord Heseltine, former Cabinet minister Steven Swinford , Deputy Political Editor 26 February 2017 • 8:54am 
L ord Heseltine has vowed to rebel against Theresa May over Brexit and back opposition efforts in the House of Lords to ensure a meaningful vote on the final outcome of exit negotiations. 
While the former Cabinet minister insisted that he is not engaging in a "confrontation" with the Government it would be "unwise" of the Prime Minister to deny Parliament a vote. 
He said Labour, Liberal Democrat and rebellious Tory colleagues ready to back a change to the Brexit Bill simply want to uphold the Supreme Court's ruling that MPs and peers have ultimate authority. 
Ministers have warned that backing the move will increase the possibility of a legal challenge against Brexit. Watch | Theresa May makes rare appearance in Lords for Brexit debate 00:40 
A Labour Lords source said the party "would be likely to win handsomely" and inflict defeat on the Government on the issue, as well as in a bid to guarantee rights of EU nationals already in the UK. 
A vote on whether Parliament should have a meaningful say on the final deal is not expected during the European Union (Notification Of Withdrawal) Bill's committee stage next week, but is more likely during report stage on March 7, the source said. 
Writing in The Mail On Sunday, Lord Heseltine said: "In the end the outcome of Brexit will have to be confirmed by Parliament. It will also have to pass in 27 national European parliaments, several sub-national parliaments and the European Parliament. Watch | PM tells Lords: Don't hold up Brexit 01:18 
"It was perhaps unwise for our Government to suppose that our Parliament should be excluded where all others were included. Very sensibly, after the Supreme Court interpreted the law, that position was reversed and Parliament was restored to its rightful constitutional role as the ultimate authority. 
"I will vote in the House of Lords to ensure that position is legally intact. This is not a confrontation with the Government which has already made such a commitment. 
"It is, put simply, a decision to ensure that the Commons has the chance to define its role in the exercise of its authority over what most people regard as the defining issue of our time." Wise words: it's called democracy MICHAEL HESELTINE https://t.co/0eqYRBUhws via @MailOnline — Anna Soubry MP (@Anna_Soubry) February 26, 2017
